questions.question: High kurtosis in a regime implies:
options: More probability mass in the center and tails (more extreme moves)
Lower variance than a normal distribution
questions.explanation: Leptokurtic distributions have fatter tails and a sharper peak than Gaussian.

questions.question: If a regime has daily mean 0.1% and standard deviation 1.2%, what is the z-score of a +3% day? (Use sd=0.012)
questions.explanation: z = (0.03 − 0.001)/0.012 ≈ 2.4167; fat tails mean such events are more common than Gaussian predicts.

questions.question: Why can fat tails make naive stop-loss distances unreliable?
questions.answer_text: Because extreme moves occur more often than Gaussian assumptions imply, stops can be hit unexpectedly.
